elements.content: Convenient generation of stable superatomic silver clusters and their systematic site-specific tailoring and directional assembly present an enduring and significant challenge. In this work, we prepared a face-centered cubic (fcc) array of Ag14 superatoms protected by face-capping 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane (C2B10H10S2) ligands, each produced from 1-thiol-o-carborane in crystallization with simultaneous reduction of Ag+ to Ag0. We find that the corner N-donor ligands contribute predominately to the stability and luminescence of the Ag14 superatom. As the first-formed nanocluster [Ag14(C2B10H10S2)6(CH3CN)8]·4CH3CN (NC-1) with labile vertex-coordinated CH3CN ligands is highly unstable, monodendate pyridine ligands were used to replace these CH3CN species site-specifically, giving [Ag14(C2B10H10S2)6(pyridine/p-methylpyridine)8] (NCs-2,3) in gram scale with its core structure intact, which features ultrastability up to 150 °C in air. Moreover, using bidentate N-containing ligands to bridge the superatomic Ag14 building blocks, we constructed an unprecedented hierarchical series of 1D-to-3D superatomic silver cluster-assembled materials (SCAM-1,2,3,4), and SCAM-4 is air-stable up to 220 °C. Furthermore, this series of stable solid-state superatomic-nanocluster materials exhibit tunable dual emission with wide-range thermochromism. The present study constitutes a major step toward the development of ligand-modulation of the structure, stability, assembly, and functionality of superatomic silver nanoclusters.
elements.clean_text: Convenient generation of stable superatomic silver clusters and their systematic site-specific tailoring and directional assembly present an enduring and significant challenge. In this work, we prepared a face-centered cubic (fcc) array of Ag14 superatoms protected by face-capping 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane (C2B10H10S2) ligands, each produced from 1-thiol-o-carborane in crystallization with simultaneous reduction of Ag+ to Ag0. We find that the corner N-donor ligands contribute predominately to the stability and luminescence of the Ag14 superatom. As the first-formed nanocluster [Ag14(C2B10H10S2)6(CH3CN)8]⋅4CH3CN (NC-1) with labile vertex-coordinated CH3CN ligands is highly unstable, monodendate pyridine ligands were used to replace these CH3CN species site-specifically, giving [Ag14(C2B10H10S2)6(pyridine/p-methylpyridine)8] (NCs-2,3) in gram scale with its core structure intact, which features ultrastability up to 150 °C in air. Moreover, using bidentate N-containing ligands to bridge the superatomic Ag14 building blocks, we constructed an unprecedented hierarchical series of 1D-to-3D superatomic silver cluster-assembled materials (SCAM-1,2,3,4), and SCAM-4 is air-stable up to 220 °C. Furthermore, this series of stable solid-state superatomic-nanocluster materials exhibit tunable dual emission with wide-range thermochromism. The present study constitutes a major step toward the development of ligand-modulation of the structure, stability, assembly, and functionality of superatomic silver nanoclusters.

elements.content: Noble metal nanoclusters (NCs) consisting of a precise number of metal atoms and ligands have attracted wide interest in recent years owing to their novel properties and potential use in various fields. Among over 100 reported Au/Ag nanoclusters with precise formulas, however, the number of superatomic silver nanoclusters is very limited because their notorious instability makes it difficult to be characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD), not to mention further detailed exploration of their properties and applications. The known nanoclusters Ag14(SR)12, Ag16(SR)14, Ag19(CCR)14, Ag20/Ag21((Se/S)2R)12, Ag25(SR)18, Ag25(CCR)20, Ag29(S2R)12, Ag32(SR)24, Ag38(SR)26, Ag63(SR)36, Ag44(SR)30, Ag50(SR)30, Ag67(SR)32, Ag74(CCPh)44, Ag136(SR)64, Ag374(SR)113, and Ag141(SR)40 are protected by entirely thiolate or alkynyl ligands, or by mixed thiolate/alkynyl and phosphine/halogen ligands, of which only rare examples such as Ag44(SR)30, Ag29(S2R)12, and Ag74(CCPh)44 are reported to be long-term stable in air and visible light at room temperature. Therefore, to obtain highly stable silver superatomic silver nanoclusters with atomically precise structure remains a great challenge, and to custom-tailor and assemble them as identical building blocks at the atomic level are even more difficult.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Noble metal nanoclusters (NCs) consisting of a precise number of metal atoms and ligands have attracted wide interest in recent years owing to their novel properties and potential use in various fields. Among over 100 reported Au/Ag nanoclusters with precise formulas, however, the number of superatomic silver nanoclusters is very limited because their notorious instability makes it difficult to be characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD), not to mention further detailed exploration of their properties and applications. The known nanoclusters Ag14(SR)12, Ag16(SR)14, Ag19(CCR)14, Ag20/Ag21((Se/S)2R)12, Ag25(SR)18, Ag25(CCR)20, Ag29(S2R)12, Ag32(SR)24, Ag38(SR)26, Ag63(SR)36, Ag44(SR)30, Ag50(SR)30, Ag67(SR)32, Ag74(CCPh)44, Ag136(SR)64, Ag374(SR)113, and Ag141(SR)40  are protected by entirely thiolate or alkynyl ligands, or by mixed thiolate/alkynyl and phosphine/halogen ligands, of which only rare examples such as Ag44(SR)30, Ag29(S2R)12, and Ag74(CCPh)44  are reported to be long-term stable in air and visible light at room temperature. Therefore, to obtain highly stable silver superatomic silver nanoclusters with atomically precise structure remains a great challenge, and to custom-tailor and assemble them as identical building blocks at the atomic level are even more difficult.

elements.content: Tailoring specific sites on a metal cluster surface can be expected to be capable of tuning their stability and functionality. However, variation of protecting motif invariably induces partial or complete dissection, resection, or even reconstruction of the metallic structure. Nanoclusters capable of keeping their metal core intact with changeable surface ligands are extremely rare. Precise manipulation of surface ligands at specific sites of a robust metal core structure is appealing but most difficult, especially for nanoclusters containing Ag0. If successful, it would provide an ideal system to fundamentally understand how the tailoring (replacing/deleting) of specific labile ligands on the cluster surface can contribute to its stability and various optical properties including absorbance and luminescence, yielding general strategies for tuning functionality and designing new superatomic silver or other metal cluster materials.
elements.clean_text: Tailoring specific sites on a metal cluster surface can be expected to be capable of tuning their stability and functionality. However, variation of protecting motif invariably induces partial or complete dissection, resection, or even reconstruction of the metallic structure. Nanoclusters capable of keeping their metal core intact with changeable surface ligands are extremely rare. Precise manipulation of surface ligands at specific sites of a robust metal core structure is appealing but most difficult, especially for nanoclusters containing Ag0. If successful, it would provide an ideal system to fundamentally understand how the tailoring (replacing/deleting) of specific labile ligands on the cluster surface can contribute to its stability and various optical properties including absorbance and luminescence, yielding general strategies for tuning functionality and designing new superatomic silver or other metal cluster materials.

elements.content: Controlled-assembly of superatomic clusters or atomically defined metal nanoclusters into extended solids are highly sought, because incorporating these unique building blocks into extended lattices would create more improved or coupled physical properties for application. The superatomic assemblies based on Co6Se8(Te8), Cr6Te8, Ni9Te6, and arsenic–metal clusters as well as Ag44(p-MBA)30, Au60S6(SCH2Ph)36, and Au246(p-MBT)80 are commonly self-assembled via weak intercluster interaction including van der Waals and H-bond interaction, etc., the atomically precise structures of which delicately revealed the driving force of hierarchal self-assembly. The high-level directional assembly of superatomic clusters via strong coordination bonding has remained underdeveloped until the appearance of a recent report showing the assembly of traditional superatomic Co6Se8 clusters into “molecules”, 2D nanocloth, nanosheet, and 3D solid with preservation of the functionality of their superatomic building blocks, which provides a new type of superatom-assembled materials. However, the absence of atomically identified stable silver entities as usable superatomic building blocks seriously hinders the development of their hierarchical and directional coordination assembly.
elements.clean_text: Controlled-assembly of superatomic clusters or atomically defined metal nanoclusters into extended solids are highly sought, because incorporating these unique building blocks into extended lattices would create more improved or coupled physical properties for application. The superatomic assemblies based on Co6Se8(Te8), Cr6Te8, Ni9Te6, and arsenic-metal clusters as well as Ag44(p-MBA)30, Au60S6(SCH2Ph)36, and Au246(p-MBT)80  are commonly self-assembled via weak intercluster interaction including van der Waals and H-bond interaction, etc., the atomically precise structures of which delicately revealed the driving force of hierarchal self-assembly. The high-level directional assembly of superatomic clusters via strong coordination bonding has remained underdeveloped until the appearance of a recent report showing the assembly of traditional superatomic Co6Se8 clusters into "molecules", 2D nanocloth, nanosheet, and 3D solid with preservation of the functionality of their superatomic building blocks, which provides a new type of superatom-assembled materials. However, the absence of atomically identified stable silver entities as usable superatomic building blocks seriously hinders the development of their hierarchical and directional coordination assembly.

elements.content: Here, for the first time, a wide footprint and functional 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane was employed to protect fcc-Ag14 clusters. The first-formed Ag0-containing superatom compound, [Ag14(C2B10H10S2)6(CH3CN)8]·4CH3CN (hereafter referred to as NC-1), was prepared via synchronous self-reduction by the 1-thiol-o-carborane ligand. With its cubic vertex sites occupied by labile CH3CN molecules, NC-1 immediately deteriorates once isolated probably due to dissociation of the coordinated solvent molecules. By site-specific replacement of vertex CH3CN with monodendate N-heteroaromatic ligands, ultrastable clusters [Ag14(C2B10H10S2)6(pyridine/p-methylpyridine)8] (NC-2,3) were prepared in gram scale. Moreover, with such desired superatomic building blocks and length-variable bidentate N-heteroaromatic ligands [pyrazine, dipyridin-4-yl-diazene (dpd), 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy), 1,4-bis­(4-pyridyl)­benzene (dpbz)], we built unprecedented 1D-to-3D superatomic silver cluster-assembled materials (SCAM-1,2,3,4) via site-specific and directional covalent-bond connection. In all, a series of 0D-to-3D materials based on superatomic silver clusters with tunable patterning, high stability, and photoluminescence were successfully prepared, in which the silver core structure and cluster emission were maintained throughout and of which NC-2,3 and SCAM-4 demonstrated high thermostability over 150 °C and 220 °C in air, respectively. The dual-emissive luminescent thermochromism of these stable superatomic silver nanocluster-based materials have also been investigated.
elements.clean_text: Here, for the first time, a wide footprint and functional 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane was employed to protect fcc-Ag14 clusters. The first-formed Ag0-containing superatom compound, [Ag14(C2B10H10S2)6(CH3CN)8]⋅4CH3CN (hereafter referred to as NC-1), was prepared via synchronous self-reduction by the 1-thiol-o-carborane ligand. With its cubic vertex sites occupied by labile CH3CN molecules, NC-1 immediately deteriorates once isolated probably due to dissociation of the coordinated solvent molecules. By site-specific replacement of vertex CH3CN with monodendate N-heteroaromatic ligands, ultrastable clusters [Ag14(C2B10H10S2)6(pyridine/p-methylpyridine)8] (NC-2,3) were prepared in gram scale. Moreover, with such desired superatomic building blocks and length-variable bidentate N-heteroaromatic ligands [pyrazine, dipyridin-4-yl-diazene (dpd), 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy), 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)benzene (dpbz)], we built unprecedented 1D-to-3D superatomic silver cluster-assembled materials (SCAM-1,2,3,4) via site-specific and directional covalent-bond connection. In all, a series of 0D-to-3D materials based on superatomic silver clusters with tunable patterning, high stability, and photoluminescence were successfully prepared, in which the silver core structure and cluster emission were maintained throughout and of which NC-2,3 and SCAM-4 demonstrated high thermostability over 150 °C and 220 °C in air, respectively. The dual-emissive luminescent thermochromism of these stable superatomic silver nanocluster-based materials have also been investigated.

elements.content: Slow evaporation of a clear CH3CN solution containing silver trifluoroacetate and 1-thiol-o-carborane at room temperature over 3 days produced superatomic cluster [Ag14(C2B10H10S2)6(CH3CN)8]·4CH3CN (NC-1) crystals in low yield, during which reduction from Ag+ to Ag0 and cluster core formation by thiol ligand occurred (). This simplified synthetic method avoided using NaBH4 as a nearly essential reductant for the synthesis of gold and silver superatomic clusters. A proposed reaction route is schematically shown ( and ), in which the disulfide bonds might first form upon oxidation by Ag ions, with subsequent rearrangement directed by coordination and structure assembly resulting in 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane, which might benefit from the enhanced reducing capacity of the thiol group modified by o-carborane with pseudoaromatic cage structure and unique electronic effect. The mass and NMR spectra exclude the existence of dithiol impurity in the monothiol ligand used (). The development of one-step metal reduction and cluster-formation by “self-reduction” of the thiol ligand is suggestive for future preparation of other mixed/variable-valence superatomic materials.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis of NC-1 by Self-Reduction of Ligand

Slow evaporation of a clear CH3CN solution containing silver trifluoroacetate and 1-thiol-o-carborane at room temperature over 3 days produced superatomic cluster [Ag14(C2B10H10S2)6(CH3CN)8]⋅4CH3CN (NC-1) crystals in low yield, during which reduction from Ag+ to Ag0 and cluster core formation by thiol ligand occurred (). This simplified synthetic method avoided using NaBH4 as a nearly essential reductant for the synthesis of gold and silver superatomic clusters. A proposed reaction route is schematically shown ( and ), in which the disulfide bonds might first form upon oxidation by Ag ions, with subsequent rearrangement directed by coordination and structure assembly resulting in 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane, which might benefit from the enhanced reducing capacity of the thiol group modified by o-carborane with pseudoaromatic cage structure and unique electronic effect. The mass and NMR spectra exclude the existence of dithiol impurity in the monothiol ligand used (). The development of one-step metal reduction and cluster-formation by "self-reduction" of the thiol ligand is suggestive for future preparation of other mixed/variable-valence superatomic materials.

elements.content: (a) Synthesis of desired Ag14 NCs; note that the (fcc) array (represented by green spheres) of Ag14 superatoms are stabilized by face-capping 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane (C2B10H10S2) ligands. (b) Structural dissection of NC-1. (c) Variable-temperature PXRD patterns of NC-2. Color codes: green and pink = silver; yellow = sulfur; gray = carbon; blue = nitrogen; turquoise = carborane.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Synthesis of desired Ag14 NCs; note that the (fcc) array (represented by green spheres) of Ag14 superatoms are stabilized by face-capping 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane (C2B10H10S2) ligands. (b) Structural dissection of NC-1. (c) Variable-temperature PXRD patterns of NC-2. Color codes: green and pink = silver; yellow = sulfur; gray = carbon; blue = nitrogen; turquoise = carborane.

elements.content: SCXRD analysis revealed that NC-1 crystallizing in triclinic space group P-1 () contains a discrete cubic Ag14 core with six face-capping bidentate 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane ligands, eight vertex-capping CH3CN ligands, and four cocrystallized CH3CN molecules (). The Ag14 metal structure adopts a typical fcc motif in a compact fashion benefiting from the presence of argentophilic Ag···Ag interactions between the octahedral Ag6 4+ inner core and its outer cubic Ag8 8+ shell, which may be ascribed to reinforcement of the bidentate 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane in the ligand shell as compared to Ag14(SC6H3F2)12(PPh3)8 (XMC-1). The unique silver core stabilized by 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane made it more robust, and the labile CH3CN ligands endow it with flexibility to be replaced by other monodentate ligand at specific vertex sites.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of NC-1 

SCXRD analysis revealed that NC-1 crystallizing in triclinic space group P-1 () contains a discrete cubic Ag14 core with six face-capping bidentate 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane ligands, eight vertex-capping CH3CN ligands, and four cocrystallized CH3CN molecules (). The Ag14 metal structure adopts a typical fcc motif in a compact fashion benefiting from the presence of argentophilic Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions between the octahedral Ag6 4+ inner core and its outer cubic Ag8 8+ shell, which may be ascribed to reinforcement of the bidentate 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane in the ligand shell as compared to Ag14(SC6H3F2)12(PPh3)8 (XMC-1). The unique silver core stabilized by 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane made it more robust, and the labile CH3CN ligands endow it with flexibility to be replaced by other monodentate ligand at specific vertex sites.

elements.content: Each Ag atom in the Ag6 4+ core adopts ten-coordinate geometry, bonding to four adjacent Ag atoms at the octahedral vertexes with an average Ag···Ag distance of 2.7635 Å, four Ag atoms from the corresponding face of the cubic Ag8 8+ shell (Ag···Ag separations in the range of 3.0822(2)–3.2896(3) Å), and two S atoms from one 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane ligand (). In the cubic Ag8 8+ shell, each Ag atom adopts seven-coordinate geometry, bonding to three S atoms from three different 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane ligands, three Ag atoms of the Ag6 4+ unit, and one CH3CN located at a cubic corner (). Each thiolate group μ3-bridges one Ag atom from the Ag6 4+ core and two Ag atoms from the Ag8 8+ shell (), where the Ag–S bond distances lie in the range of 2.4539(1) Å–2.7275(2) Å.
elements.clean_text: Each Ag atom in the Ag6 4+ core adopts ten-coordinate geometry, bonding to four adjacent Ag atoms at the octahedral vertexes with an average Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distance of 2.7635 Å, four Ag atoms from the corresponding face of the cubic Ag8 8+ shell (Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag separations in the range of 3.0822(2)-3.2896(3) Å), and two S atoms from one 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane ligand (). In the cubic Ag8 8+ shell, each Ag atom adopts seven-coordinate geometry, bonding to three S atoms from three different 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane ligands, three Ag atoms of the Ag6 4+ unit, and one CH3CN located at a cubic corner (). Each thiolate group μ3-bridges one Ag atom from the Ag6 4+ core and two Ag atoms from the Ag8 8+ shell (), where the Ag-S bond distances lie in the range of 2.4539(1) Å-2.7275(2) Å.

elements.content: Extensive structural characterizations except SCXRD of NC-1 are limited due to the unsatisfactory yield and difficult repetition, as well as poor stability of the isolated cluster product. We also failed to obtain intact molecular ion species of NC-1 in both positive and negative modes even by using an electrospray ionization source. Despite being the cause of instability of NC-1, the labile CH3CN ligands at the cubic vertices also provide an excellent opportunity to modify its coordination shell by ligand replacement or exchange.
elements.clean_text: Extensive structural characterizations except SCXRD of NC-1 are limited due to the unsatisfactory yield and difficult repetition, as well as poor stability of the isolated cluster product. We also failed to obtain intact molecular ion species of NC-1 in both positive and negative modes even by using an electrospray ionization source. Despite being the cause of instability of NC-1, the labile CH3CN ligands at the cubic vertices also provide an excellent opportunity to modify its coordination shell by ligand replacement or exchange.

elements.content: To tackle the issue of stability, we used monodentate N-heteroaromatic ligands to site-specifically replace the surface-coordinated CH3CN species () and obtained NC-2,3 with retention of the metal core structure. As expected, NC-2,3 showed increased propensity to self-assemble into macroscopic crystals with highly increased synthetic yield and enhanced stability. illustrates the structures of N-containing ligands employed for this purpose. In a typical synthesis, NC-2 precipitated immediately in large scale with high phase purity (), as soon as pyridine in dichloromethane was added into the reaction system of NC-1; the propensity is similar to the conversion from Ag29(BDT)12 to Ag29(BDT)12(TPP)4 (BDT = 1,3-benzenedithiol, TPP = triphenylphosphine).
elements.clean_text:
Site-Specific Tailoring and Functionalizing Superatoms

To tackle the issue of stability, we used monodentate N-heteroaromatic ligands to site-specifically replace the surface-coordinated CH3CN species () and obtained NC-2,3 with retention of the metal core structure. As expected, NC-2,3 showed increased propensity to self-assemble into macroscopic crystals with highly increased synthetic yield and enhanced stability.  illustrates the structures of N-containing ligands employed for this purpose. In a typical synthesis, NC-2 precipitated immediately in large scale with high phase purity (), as soon as pyridine in dichloromethane was added into the reaction system of NC-1; the propensity is similar to the conversion from Ag29(BDT)12 to Ag29(BDT)12(TPP)4 (BDT = 1,3-benzenedithiol, TPP = triphenylphosphine).

elements.content: Good-quality pale yellow single crystals of NC-2,3 were obtained by room-temperature reaction of 1-thiol-o-carborane (0.1 mmol) and AgCF3COO (0.2 mmol) in 4 mL of acetonitrile solution with subsequent addition of pyridine/p-methylpyridine (0.01 mmol) in 2 mL of CH2Cl2 for 3 days. Yield: ca. 35% (based on 1-thiol-o-carborane). SCXRD analyses revealed that NC-2,3 crystallize in orthorhombic Pbca and tetragonal I4/m space groups, respectively. The vertices of the cubic shell are occupied by the exchanged pyridyl ligands, and the similar metal core is retained except for slight variation of the Ag···Ag distances ( and ).
elements.clean_text: Good-quality pale yellow single crystals of NC-2,3 were obtained by room-temperature reaction of 1-thiol-o-carborane (0.1 mmol) and AgCF3COO (0.2 mmol) in 4 mL of acetonitrile solution with subsequent addition of pyridine/p-methylpyridine (0.01 mmol) in 2 mL of CH2Cl2 for 3 days. Yield: ca. 35% (based on 1-thiol-o-carborane). SCXRD analyses revealed that NC-2,3 crystallize in orthorhombic Pbca and tetragonal I4/m space groups, respectively. The vertices of the cubic shell are occupied by the exchanged pyridyl ligands, and the similar metal core is retained except for slight variation of the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distances ( and ).

elements.content: The formula and phase purity of NC-2,3 have been confirmed by TG (), EDS (), ESI-TOF-MS (), and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) ( and ). The XPS survey spectrum of NC-2 showed all the expected elements and a Ag 3d5/2 (BE of 368.26 eV) peak similar to those in other silver nanoparticles, suggesting the presence of Ag0 in the cluster (). TEM images revealed that NC-2,3 exist as discrete particles with average size of approximate 2.0 nm in DMF solution, which is close to the maximum C···C separation in the cluster (1.77 and 2.06 nm) obtained from X-ray analyses (). Most excitingly, NC-2,3 retain their crystallinity over 150 °C in air, as demonstrated by in situ PXRD measurements (c and ); their photoluminescence spectra also remain unchanged until 150 °C (). The ESI-MS of NC-3 after thermal treatment at 150 °C was reproducible (), while the high temperature makes NC-2 insoluble in various solvents. Such high thermostability in air with light is very scarce for silver nanoclusters with precise structure, which may be ascribed to the complete geometric shell closing formed by the 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane and pyridines, as can be shown by the comparison of charge analysis between NC-1 and NC-1 without CH3CN (), in addition to their intrinsic closed-shell superatom electronic structures.
elements.clean_text: The formula and phase purity of NC-2,3 have been confirmed by TG (), EDS (), ESI-TOF-MS (), and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) ( and ). The XPS survey spectrum of NC-2 showed all the expected elements and a Ag 3d5/2 (BE of 368.26 eV) peak similar to those in other silver nanoparticles, suggesting the presence of Ag0 in the cluster (). TEM images revealed that NC-2,3 exist as discrete particles with average size of approximate 2.0 nm in DMF solution, which is close to the maximum C⋅⋅⋅C separation in the cluster (1.77 and 2.06 nm) obtained from X-ray analyses (). Most excitingly, NC-2,3 retain their crystallinity over 150 °C in air, as demonstrated by in situ PXRD measurements (c and ); their photoluminescence spectra also remain unchanged until 150 °C (). The ESI-MS of NC-3 after thermal treatment at 150 °C was reproducible (), while the high temperature makes NC-2 insoluble in various solvents. Such high thermostability in air with light is very scarce for silver nanoclusters with precise structure, which may be ascribed to the complete geometric shell closing formed by the 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane and pyridines, as can be shown by the comparison of charge analysis between NC-1 and NC-1 without CH3CN (), in addition to their intrinsic closed-shell superatom electronic structures.

elements.content: The success of site-specific tailoring of NC-1 with monodentate ligands and the developed assembly strategies for cluster-based materials including metal–organic frameworks, metal–organic polyhedra, and the recent-reported superatomic Co6Se8 assembled crystalline materials via metal–ligand coordination bonding greatly inspired us to create a wide variety of preprogrammed architectures using the silver superatom as building block via site-specific coordination connection by multitopic ligands. However, the attempts with bitopic linkers following the above ligand-exchange synthetic procedure failed owing to fast polymerization so that we could not obtain single crystals by this approach. Therefore, we planned to bypass the obstacle by using 1,2-dithiol-o-carborane instead (see detailed synthesis in ), because the 1,2-dithiolate-o-carboranes are the final components in the desired superatomic nanoclusters. The optimized synthesis procedure is as follows: we first reacted 1,2-dithiol-o-carborane and AgCF3COO in CH3CN to afford the stoichoimetric precursor [Ag2(C2B10H10S2)­(CH3CN)2] n , which displays a 2D layer structure (). This precursor was then dissolved in DMF, which was followed by addition of bitopic ligands such as pyrazine or bipyridines in CH3CN. As a result, the desired single crystals of silver superatomic cluster-assembled materials (SCAM-n , n = 1, 2, 3, 4) containing the identical 1,2- dithiolate-o-carborane-protected silver core as that in NC-1,2,3 with tunable dimensionality and patterning from 1D to 3D were afforded in about 3 days (). Their phase purities were confirmed with PXRD measurements ().
elements.clean_text:
Assembly and Structures of Superatomic Silver Cluster Networks

The success of site-specific tailoring of NC-1 with monodentate ligands and the developed assembly strategies for cluster-based materials including metal-organic frameworks, metal-organic polyhedra, and the recent-reported superatomic Co6Se8 assembled crystalline materials via metal-ligand coordination bonding greatly inspired us to create a wide variety of preprogrammed architectures using the silver superatom as building block via site-specific coordination connection by multitopic ligands. However, the attempts with bitopic linkers following the above ligand-exchange synthetic procedure failed owing to fast polymerization so that we could not obtain single crystals by this approach. Therefore, we planned to bypass the obstacle by using 1,2-dithiol-o-carborane instead (see detailed synthesis in ), because the 1,2-dithiolate-o-carboranes are the final components in the desired superatomic nanoclusters. The optimized synthesis procedure is as follows: we first reacted 1,2-dithiol-o-carborane and AgCF3COO in CH3CN to afford the stoichoimetric precursor [Ag2(C2B10H10S2)(CH3CN)2] n , which displays a 2D layer structure (). This precursor was then dissolved in DMF, which was followed by addition of bitopic ligands such as pyrazine or bipyridines in CH3CN. As a result, the desired single crystals of silver superatomic cluster-assembled materials (SCAM-n , n = 1, 2, 3, 4) containing the identical 1,2- dithiolate-o-carborane-protected silver core as that in NC-1,2,3 with tunable dimensionality and patterning from 1D to 3D were afforded in about 3 days (). Their phase purities were confirmed with PXRD measurements ().

elements.content: Structural represention of (a) 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane-capped superatomic silver cluster, (b) 1D helix of SCAM-1, (c) 2D grid network of SCAM-2, (d) 3D porous framework of SCAM-3, and (e) 2-fold interpenetrated porous 3D frameworks of SCAM-4. (f) Variable-temperature PXRD of SCAM-4 from 25 °C to 350 °C.
elements.clean_text: 2  Structural represention of (a) 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane-capped superatomic silver cluster, (b) 1D helix of SCAM-1, (c) 2D grid network of SCAM-2, (d) 3D porous framework of SCAM-3, and (e) 2-fold interpenetrated porous 3D frameworks of SCAM-4. (f) Variable-temperature PXRD of SCAM-4 from 25 °C to 350 °C.

elements.content: Single-crystal structural analysis revealed that SCAM-1 crystallizes in trigonal space group P32. The asymmetric unit contains two cocrystallized DMAc molecules and one Ag14(C2B10H10S2)6 cluster identical to that in NCs coprotected by six and a half pyrazine, one DMAc, and half a CH3CN molecules. As expected, the fcc motifs in SCAM-1 are bridged by pyrazines to afford a polymeric structure. However, owing to the small size of the ligand, steric hindrance limits higher-dimensional framework construction. Interestingly, the clusters are bridged only in the diagonal direction by the pyrazines, resulting in a right-handed helix along the c axis (b and ). Complex SCAM-2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/m and exhibits a 2D network structure. The clusters in SCAM-2 are coprotected by four CH3CN and four dipyridin-4-yl-diazene ligands. The trans-bipyridyl ligands further link the cluster nodes into an extensive sheet with rhomboidal grids of sides 1.4 × 1.4 nm, and the layers adopt a AB stacking pattern perpendicular to the a axis (). As expected, the longer linker extends the dimensionality of cluster-assembled materials. Nevertheless, the stability of these two polymeric complexes are quite low probably due to their easily dislodged coordinating solvent molecules, which is akin to NC-1. It is expected that use of the more adaptable linker would be able to yield higher-dimensional cluster-assembled materials. Complex SCAM-3 crystallizes in tetragonal space group P4mn/c with 1/8 cluster in the asymmetric unit. The 3D framework in SCAM-3 was assembled with all eight vertices of the fcc cluster coprotected with linear 4,4′-bipyridines. The second building units (SBUs) can be seen as octahedral cages with six clusters on the vertices and six ligands on the edges. Channels with cross section of 1.3 × 1.8 nm with inward-pointing o-carborane groups are observed along the c axis in the framework. The overall structure of SCAM-3 displays a bcu topological network with the Schläfli symbol 424.64 (d and ). However, SCAM-3 still exhibits poor stability, which could be attributed to the absence of sufficient framework rigidity after the escape of volatile solvent molecules from the huge pore (solvent accessible volume is 57.5% calculated by Platon). Even so, SCAM-3 further supported the validity of our assembly strategy.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal structural analysis revealed that SCAM-1 crystallizes in trigonal space group P32. The asymmetric unit contains two cocrystallized DMAc molecules and one Ag14(C2B10H10S2)6 cluster identical to that in NCs coprotected by six and a half pyrazine, one DMAc, and half a CH3CN molecules. As expected, the fcc motifs in SCAM-1 are bridged by pyrazines to afford a polymeric structure. However, owing to the small size of the ligand, steric hindrance limits higher-dimensional framework construction. Interestingly, the clusters are bridged only in the diagonal direction by the pyrazines, resulting in a right-handed helix along the c axis (b and ). Complex SCAM-2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/m and exhibits a 2D network structure. The clusters in SCAM-2 are coprotected by four CH3CN and four dipyridin-4-yl-diazene ligands. The trans-bipyridyl ligands further link the cluster nodes into an extensive sheet with rhomboidal grids of sides 1.4 × 1.4 nm, and the layers adopt a AB stacking pattern perpendicular to the a axis (). As expected, the longer linker extends the dimensionality of cluster-assembled materials. Nevertheless, the stability of these two polymeric complexes are quite low probably due to their easily dislodged coordinating solvent molecules, which is akin to NC-1. It is expected that use of the more adaptable linker would be able to yield higher-dimensional cluster-assembled materials. Complex SCAM-3 crystallizes in tetragonal space group P4mn/c with 1/8 cluster in the asymmetric unit. The 3D framework in SCAM-3 was assembled with all eight vertices of the fcc cluster coprotected with linear 4,4'-bipyridines. The second building units (SBUs) can be seen as octahedral cages with six clusters on the vertices and six ligands on the edges. Channels with cross section of 1.3 × 1.8 nm with inward-pointing o-carborane groups are observed along the c axis in the framework. The overall structure of SCAM-3 displays a bcu topological network with the Schläfli symbol 424.64 (d and ). However, SCAM-3 still exhibits poor stability, which could be attributed to the absence of sufficient framework rigidity after the escape of volatile solvent molecules from the huge pore (solvent accessible volume is 57.5% calculated by Platon). Even so, SCAM-3 further supported the validity of our assembly strategy.

elements.content: Interpenetration (catenation) has long been considered as a major impediment in the achievement of stable and porous crystalline structures. We utilized an alternative longer linker, 1,4-bis­(4-pyridyl)­benzene, to facilitate interpenetration. As expected, the desired complex SCAM-4 adopts a topological structure identical with that of SCAM-3 but crystallizes in tetragonal space group I41/a and contains a pair of parallel interwoven 3D frameworks that are mutually reinforced (e and ). Furthermore, five carborane moieties on the thiolated ligands of each cluster node occupy the interstice with one pointing to the channel along the a axis. Thus, the high porosity in SCAM-4 (45.4%, 0.1075 cm3/g) still remains after interpenetration with a pore size of ca. 1.12 nm and surface area of 69.3 m2/g substantiated by N2 adsorption measurement (). Thermoanalysis and variable-temperature PXRD indicated the high stability of SCAM-4 up to about 220 °C (f and ) which, combined with broad absorbance in the UV–vis region (a), would hold promise for some functionality in photocatalysis and other solar-energy-harvesting applications. The achieved results fully demonstrated that noble coinage-metal (Au and Ag) superatomic clusters are alternative building blocks for patterning materials and porous materials. The present synthetic strategy is generally applicable for other bidentate N-containing ligands, and it is anticipated that more suitable superatomic cluster candidates could be prepared for hierarchical assembly.

We utilized an alternative longer linker, 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)benzene, to facilitate interpenetration. As expected, the desired complex SCAM-4 adopts a topological structure identical with that of SCAM-3 but crystallizes in tetragonal space group I41/a and contains a pair of parallel interwoven 3D frameworks that are mutually reinforced (e and ). Furthermore, five carborane moieties on the thiolated ligands of each cluster node occupy the interstice with one pointing to the channel along the a axis. Thus, the high porosity in SCAM-4 (45.4%, 0.1075 cm3/g) still remains after interpenetration with a pore size of ca. 1.12 nm and surface area of 69.3 m2/g substantiated by N2 adsorption measurement (). Thermoanalysis and variable-temperature PXRD indicated the high stability of SCAM-4 up to about 220 °C (f and ) which, combined with broad absorbance in the UV-vis region (a), would hold promise for some functionality in photocatalysis and other solar-energy-harvesting applications. The achieved results fully demonstrated that noble coinage-metal (Au and Ag) superatomic clusters are alternative building blocks for patterning materials and porous materials. The present synthetic strategy is generally applicable for other bidentate N-containing ligands, and it is anticipated that more suitable superatomic cluster candidates could be prepared for hierarchical assembly.

elements.content: (a) Computed optical absorption spectrum of the cluster NC-2 (black) compared to the experimental data (blue). Gray bars show the individual transitions (delta-function-like peaks showing the relative oscillator strengths) (Table S1). The continuous computational spectrum is sums of Gaussian smoothed individual transitions (width of 15 nm). The intensity of the computational spectrum is scaled so that the dominant peaks are approximately of similar intensity. (b) HOMO of NC-2 with its S-symmetric wave function localized at the Ag6 octahedron (isosurface cutoff of 0.04 au) (left), and schematic diagram of s-orbital is shown for illustrative purposes (right). (c) LUMO to LUMO+2 of NC-2 with their P-symmetric wave function localized overall the Ag14 unit (isosurface cutoff of 0.04 au) (left), and schematic diagram of p-orbital is shown for illustrative purposes (right). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Computed optical absorption spectrum of the cluster NC-2 (black) compared to the experimental data (blue). Gray bars show the individual transitions (delta-function-like peaks showing the relative oscillator strengths) (Table S1). The continuous computational spectrum is sums of Gaussian smoothed individual transitions (width of 15 nm). The intensity of the computational spectrum is scaled so that the dominant peaks are approximately of similar intensity. (b) HOMO of NC-2 with its S-symmetric wave function localized at the Ag6 octahedron (isosurface cutoff of 0.04 au) (left), and schematic diagram of s-orbital is shown for illustrative purposes (right). (c) LUMO to LUMO+2 of NC-2 with their P-symmetric wave function localized overall the Ag14 unit (isosurface cutoff of 0.04 au) (left), and schematic diagram of p-orbital is shown for illustrative purposes (right). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The composition of NC-2 indicates that it has 2 “free” metallic electrons by applying the superatom counting rule (14 electrons from the metal, 12 electrons withdrawn by the ligands). The visualization of HOMO clearly indicates that the S-symmetric wave function only localizes in the deep core of the cluster within the Ag6 octahedron. It also has a significant weight on localized atomic orbital components at the S atoms (b). Thus, HOMO might not be classified as a strict superatomic state. Nevertheless, the nearly degenerate lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMO to LUMO+2) present strong P character over the whole Ag14 cube, which could be assigned to P superatomic states (c).
elements.clean_text:
Optical Absorption of NC-2,3 and SCAM-4, and Superatomic Molecular Orbitals for NC-2 

The composition of NC-2 indicates that it has 2 "free" metallic electrons by applying the superatom counting rule (14 electrons from the metal, 12 electrons withdrawn by the ligands). The visualization of HOMO clearly indicates that the S-symmetric wave function only localizes in the deep core of the cluster within the Ag6 octahedron. It also has a significant weight on localized atomic orbital components at the S atoms (b). Thus, HOMO might not be classified as a strict superatomic state. Nevertheless, the nearly degenerate lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMO to LUMO+2) present strong P character over the whole Ag14 cube, which could be assigned to P superatomic states (c).

elements.content: To identify the origin of the optical transitions, we simulated the optical absorption of NC-2 by density functional theory. The DMF solution of crystalline NC-2 yielded molecular-like absorption spectra, with a main band at 314 nm and a weak peak at ∼378 nm corresponding to the simulated peak at 314 nm (HOMO–5 → LUMO+2) and 352 nm (HOMO → LUMO) respectively, both of which involved the 1P levels in the superatom theory (c). The gap between the calculated low energy peak (352 nm) and the experimental value (∼378 nm) may be related to the interactions between either nanoclusters or nanoclusters and solvent molecules. Upon crystallization, the band edge further red-shifts and the absorption feature becomes a structureless broader band from 300 to 500 nm with the band edge extending to 700 nm, which could be ascribed to electronic coupling between the NCs via interaction between the transition dipole moment of the individual absorbing NC-2 and induced dipole moments in the neighboring NC-2. A similar relationship between the UV–vis absorption spectra of solid and dissolved material was reported previously for other metal nanoclusters, such as silver nanocluster (Ag29(BDT)12(TPP)4), CdSe nanocluster, and ZnTe nanocluster. In contrast, two absorption bands of XMC-1 with a relatively “loose” Ag14 core appeared at 368 and 530 nm from cluster and ligand-to-ligand transitions, respectively. The distinct difference that resulted from the different natures of their metal–core structures, despite their similar appearance, fully demonstrated that the optical absorption properties of nanoclusters are highly sensitive to their metal core structures.
elements.clean_text: To identify the origin of the optical transitions, we simulated the optical absorption of NC-2 by density functional theory. The DMF solution of crystalline NC-2 yielded molecular-like absorption spectra, with a main band at 314 nm and a weak peak at ~378 nm corresponding to the simulated peak at 314 nm (HOMO-5 → LUMO+2) and 352 nm (HOMO → LUMO) respectively, both of which involved the 1P levels in the superatom theory (c). The gap between the calculated low energy peak (352 nm) and the experimental value (~378 nm) may be related to the interactions between either nanoclusters or nanoclusters and solvent molecules. Upon crystallization, the band edge further red-shifts and the absorption feature becomes a structureless broader band from 300 to 500 nm with the band edge extending to 700 nm, which could be ascribed to electronic coupling between the NCs via interaction between the transition dipole moment of the individual absorbing NC-2 and induced dipole moments in the neighboring NC-2. A similar relationship between the UV-vis absorption spectra of solid and dissolved material was reported previously for other metal nanoclusters, such as silver nanocluster (Ag29(BDT)12(TPP)4), CdSe nanocluster, and ZnTe nanocluster. In contrast, two absorption bands of XMC-1 with a relatively "loose" Ag14 core appeared at 368 and 530 nm from cluster and ligand-to-ligand transitions, respectively. The distinct difference that resulted from the different natures of their metal-core structures, despite their similar appearance, fully demonstrated that the optical absorption properties of nanoclusters are highly sensitive to their metal core structures.

elements.content: Luminescence is one of the most important properties for coinage-metal nanoclusters, which usually lies in the visible-near-infrared window with a large Stokes shift and has potential applications in various sensing applications. However, among pure silver superatomic clusters with well-defined structures, only Ag14(SR)12 (yellow visible at RT, unstable), Ag16(SR)14 and Ag32(SR)24 (blue invisible at RT, unstable), Ag25(SR)18 (near-infrared, unstable), and Ag29(S2R)12 (red invisible at RT, stable) showed very weak photoluminescence at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence of NC-2,3 and SCAM-4 

Luminescence is one of the most important properties for coinage-metal nanoclusters, which usually lies in the visible-near-infrared window with a large Stokes shift and has potential applications in various sensing applications. However, among pure silver superatomic clusters with well-defined structures, only Ag14(SR)12 (yellow visible at RT, unstable), Ag16(SR)14  and Ag32(SR)24  (blue invisible at RT, unstable), Ag25(SR)18 (near-infrared, unstable), and Ag29(S2R)12  (red invisible at RT, stable) showed very weak photoluminescence at room temperature.

elements.content: In view of the high stability of NC-2,3 and SCAM-4, their temperature-dependent solid-state emissions were measured. Their excitation spectra at 298 K display broad bands which agree well with the corresponding electronic absorption spectra (a, ). At room temperature, NC-2 displays a dominant band with an emission maximum at 595 nm and a shoulder peak at 668 nm (λex = 370 nm), designated as a LE band with quantum yield (QY) of 2.1%. As the temperature decreases, the LE emission intensity gradually increases until 123 K along with an obvious red shift of the main emission (from 595 to 622 nm). Below 113 K, a higher-energy (HE) band centered at 510 nm arises and increases fast accompanied by a slightly decrease of the LE emission, resulting in a typical dual emission feature (a). The microsecond-scale emissive lifetime of the LE emission bands (τ83 K = 298.23 μs and τ298 K = 7.85 μs) indicates the characteristics of phosphorescence, probably originating from the superatom cluster center, while the HE emission arising at low temperature also exhibits microsecond lifetime (τ83 K = 20.17 μs), which tentatively originates from CLCT (cluster to ligand charge transition) modified by the interactions between the metal core and surface ligand, because the site-specific modification and assembly of superatoms led to the distinct difference of HE emission in NC-2, NC-3 (), and SCAM-4 (b). The methylpyridine of NC-3 results in a redshift of HE bands and different temperature-dependent fluorescent color (orange-to-red from 83 K to 293 K) compared with NC-2. For SCAM-4, the HE emission (centered at 518 nm) component becomes more dominated at low temperature (lower than 263 K), while the LE band grows weaker with decreasing temperature and disappears at 83 K, which may be ascribed to the electronic interaction between superatom clusters with the rigid and conjugated π-systems of the linkers. As a result, thermochromism ranging more widely from green to red of SCAM-4 was observed. These findings imply the feasibility of facile modulation of the luminescent properties of the superatomic clusters and cluster-based assembled materials through the appropriate choice of ligand modules or linkers, which may lead to the evolution of novel cluster-based materials with unique properties and functions.

As the temperature decreases, the LE emission intensity gradually increases until 123 K along with an obvious red shift of the main emission (from 595 to 622 nm). Below 113 K, a higher-energy (HE) band centered at 510 nm arises and increases fast accompanied by a slightly decrease of the LE emission, resulting in a typical dual emission feature (a). The microsecond-scale emissive lifetime of the LE emission bands (τ83 K = 298.23 μs and τ298 K = 7.85 μs) indicates the characteristics of phosphorescence, probably originating from the superatom cluster center, while the HE emission arising at low temperature also exhibits microsecond lifetime (τ83 K = 20.17 μs), which tentatively originates from CLCT (cluster to ligand charge transition) modified by the interactions between the metal core and surface ligand, because the site-specific modification and assembly of superatoms led to the distinct difference of HE emission in NC-2, NC-3 (), and SCAM-4 (b). The methylpyridine of NC-3 results in a redshift of HE bands and different temperature-dependent fluorescent color (orange-to-red from 83 K to 293 K) compared with NC-2. For SCAM-4, the HE emission (centered at 518 nm) component becomes more dominated at low temperature (lower than 263 K), while the LE band grows weaker with decreasing temperature and disappears at 83 K, which may be ascribed to the electronic interaction between superatom clusters with the rigid and conjugated π-systems of the linkers. As a result, thermochromism ranging more widely from green to red of SCAM-4 was observed. These findings imply the feasibility of facile modulation of the luminescent properties of the superatomic clusters and cluster-based assembled materials through the appropriate choice of ligand modules or linkers, which may lead to the evolution of novel cluster-based materials with unique properties and functions.

elements.content: Variable-temperature emission spectra of (a) solid-state NC-2 (exited at 370 nm) and (b) the evacuated SCAM-4 (excited at 380 nm) from 83 K to 298 K in air. Inset: the corresponding photographs of NC-2 and SCAM-4 under 365 nm UV irradiation.
elements.clean_text: 4  Variable-temperature emission spectra of (a) solid-state NC-2 (exited at 370 nm) and (b) the evacuated SCAM-4 (excited at 380 nm) from 83 K to 298 K in air. Inset: the corresponding photographs of NC-2 and SCAM-4 under 365 nm UV irradiation.

elements.content: In summary, 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane was employed in the ligand shell to protect a 2e fcc-Ag14 superatom. The one-pot synthesis involved synchronous Ag+ to Ag0 by self-reduction of the thiol ligand and the formation of the unstable superatomic silver cluster NC-1. Site-specific surface modification of NC-1 with pyridyl-type ligands afforded highly thermostable superatomic clusters. Moreover, various 1D-to-3D superatomic silver cluster-assembled materials were predesigned and obtained through progressively optimized ligand-bridging approach. More importantly, the site-specific tailoring and assembly strategy with organic ligands not only greatly improved the stability but also modulated the emission properties of the target materials. Variable dual-emissive thermochromism in a wide visible-light range in the solid state are observed. The modification and assembly strategies of surface ligands of superatoms provided a direct way to understand the surface functionalization–property relationship and produce new functional materials. These types of stable emissive isolated clusters and porous cluster-assembled materials are expected to find utility in a range of potential applications such as sensing, imaging, and optics. To demonstrate the universal property of this strategy, extensive work including site-specifically surface modification of group 11 and other noble-metal nanoclusters with various functionalized ligands is underway in our lab.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, 1,2-dithiolate-o-carborane was employed in the ligand shell to protect a 2e fcc-Ag14 superatom. The one-pot synthesis involved synchronous Ag+ to Ag0 by self-reduction of the thiol ligand and the formation of the unstable superatomic silver cluster NC-1. Site-specific surface modification of NC-1 with pyridyl-type ligands afforded highly thermostable superatomic clusters. Moreover, various 1D-to-3D superatomic silver cluster-assembled materials were predesigned and obtained through progressively optimized ligand-bridging approach. More importantly, the site-specific tailoring and assembly strategy with organic ligands not only greatly improved the stability but also modulated the emission properties of the target materials. Variable dual-emissive thermochromism in a wide visible-light range in the solid state are observed. The modification and assembly strategies of surface ligands of superatoms provided a direct way to understand the surface functionalization-property relationship and produce new functional materials. These types of stable emissive isolated clusters and porous cluster-assembled materials are expected to find utility in a range of potential applications such as sensing, imaging, and optics. To demonstrate the universal property of this strategy, extensive work including site-specifically surface modification of group 11 and other noble-metal nanoclusters with various functionalized ligands is underway in our lab.

cln_elements.content: Good-quality pale yellow single crystals of NC-2,3 were obtained by room-temperature reaction of 1-thiol-o-carborane (0.1 mmol) and AgCF3COO (0.2 mmol) in 4 mL of acetonitrile solution with subsequent addition of pyridine/p-methylpyridine (0.01 mmol) in 2 mL of CH2Cl2 for 3 days. Yield: ca. 35% (based on 1-thiol-o-carborane). SCXRD analyses revealed that NC-2,3 crystallize in orthorhombic Pbca and tetragonal I4/m space groups, respectively. The vertices of the cubic shell are occupied by the exchanged pyridyl ligands, and the similar metal core is retained except for slight variation of the Ag···Ag distances ( and ).
cln_elements.clean_text: Good-quality pale yellow single crystals of NC-2,3 were obtained by room-temperature reaction of 1-thiol-o-carborane (0.1 mmol) and AgCF3COO (0.2 mmol) in 4 mL of acetonitrile solution with subsequent addition of pyridine/p-methylpyridine (0.01 mmol) in 2 mL of CH2Cl2 for 3 days. Yield: ca. 35% (based on 1-thiol-o-carborane). SCXRD analyses revealed that NC-2,3 crystallize in orthorhombic Pbca and tetragonal I4/m space groups, respectively. The vertices of the cubic shell are occupied by the exchanged pyridyl ligands, and the similar metal core is retained except for slight variation of the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distances ( and ).

cln_elements.content:
Interpenetration (catenation) has long been considered as a major impediment in the achievement of stable and porous crystalline structures. We utilized an alternative longer linker, 1,4-bis­(4-pyridyl)­benzene, to facilitate interpenetration. As expected, the desired complex SCAM-4 adopts a topological structure identical with that of SCAM-3 but crystallizes in tetragonal space group I41/a and contains a pair of parallel interwoven 3D frameworks that are mutually reinforced (e and ). Furthermore, five carborane moieties on the thiolated ligands of each cluster node occupy the interstice with one pointing to the channel along the a axis. Thus, the high porosity in SCAM-4 (45.4%, 0.1075 cm3/g) still remains after interpenetration with a pore size of ca. 1.12 nm and surface area of 69.3 m2/g substantiated by N2 adsorption measurement (). Thermoanalysis and variable-temperature PXRD indicated the high stability of SCAM-4 up to about 220 °C (f and ) which, combined with broad absorbance in the UV–vis region (a), would hold promise for some functionality in photocatalysis and other solar-energy-harvesting applications. The achieved results fully demonstrated that noble coinage-metal (Au and Ag) superatomic clusters are alternative building blocks for patterning materials and porous materials. The present synthetic strategy is generally applicable for other bidentate N-containing ligands, and it is anticipated that more suitable superatomic cluster candidates could be prepared for hierarchical assembly.

In view of the high stability of NC-2,3 and SCAM-4, their temperature-dependent solid-state emissions were measured. Their excitation spectra at 298 K display broad bands which agree well with the corresponding electronic absorption spectra (a, ). At room temperature, NC-2 displays a dominant band with an emission maximum at 595 nm and a shoulder peak at 668 nm (λex = 370 nm), designated as a LE band with quantum yield (QY) of 2.1%. As the temperature decreases, the LE emission intensity gradually increases until 123 K along with an obvious red shift of the main emission (from 595 to 622 nm). Below 113 K, a higher-energy (HE) band centered at 510 nm arises and increases fast accompanied by a slightly decrease of the LE emission, resulting in a typical dual emission feature (a). The microsecond-scale emissive lifetime of the LE emission bands (τ83 K = 298.23 μs and τ298 K = 7.85 μs) indicates the characteristics of phosphorescence, probably originating from the superatom cluster center, while the HE emission arising at low temperature also exhibits microsecond lifetime (τ83 K = 20.17 μs), which tentatively originates from CLCT (cluster to ligand charge transition) modified by the interactions between the metal core and surface ligand, because the site-specific modification and assembly of superatoms led to the distinct difference of HE emission in NC-2, NC-3 (), and SCAM-4 (b). The methylpyridine of NC-3 results in a redshift of HE bands and different temperature-dependent fluorescent color (orange-to-red from 83 K to 293 K) compared with NC-2. For SCAM-4, the HE emission (centered at 518 nm) component becomes more dominated at low temperature (lower than 263 K), while the LE band grows weaker with decreasing temperature and disappears at 83 K, which may be ascribed to the electronic interaction between superatom clusters with the rigid and conjugated π-systems of the linkers. As a result, thermochromism ranging more widely from green to red of SCAM-4 was observed. These findings imply the feasibility of facile modulation of the luminescent properties of the superatomic clusters and cluster-based assembled materials through the appropriate choice of ligand modules or linkers, which may lead to the evolution of novel cluster-based materials with unique properties and functions.

Interpenetration (catenation) has long been considered as a major impediment in the achievement of stable and porous crystalline structures. We utilized an alternative longer linker, 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)benzene, to facilitate interpenetration. As expected, the desired complex SCAM-4 adopts a topological structure identical with that of SCAM-3 but crystallizes in tetragonal space group I41/a and contains a pair of parallel interwoven 3D frameworks that are mutually reinforced (e and ). Furthermore, five carborane moieties on the thiolated ligands of each cluster node occupy the interstice with one pointing to the channel along the a axis. Thus, the high porosity in SCAM-4 (45.4%, 0.1075 cm3/g) still remains after interpenetration with a pore size of ca. 1.12 nm and surface area of 69.3 m2/g substantiated by N2 adsorption measurement (). Thermoanalysis and variable-temperature PXRD indicated the high stability of SCAM-4 up to about 220 °C (f and ) which, combined with broad absorbance in the UV-vis region (a), would hold promise for some functionality in photocatalysis and other solar-energy-harvesting applications. The achieved results fully demonstrated that noble coinage-metal (Au and Ag) superatomic clusters are alternative building blocks for patterning materials and porous materials. The present synthetic strategy is generally applicable for other bidentate N-containing ligands, and it is anticipated that more suitable superatomic cluster candidates could be prepared for hierarchical assembly.

In view of the high stability of NC-2,3 and SCAM-4, their temperature-dependent solid-state emissions were measured. Their excitation spectra at 298 K display broad bands which agree well with the corresponding electronic absorption spectra (a, ). At room temperature, NC-2 displays a dominant band with an emission maximum at 595 nm and a shoulder peak at 668 nm (λex = 370 nm), designated as a LE band with quantum yield (QY) of 2.1%. As the temperature decreases, the LE emission intensity gradually increases until 123 K along with an obvious red shift of the main emission (from 595 to 622 nm). Below 113 K, a higher-energy (HE) band centered at 510 nm arises and increases fast accompanied by a slightly decrease of the LE emission, resulting in a typical dual emission feature (a). The microsecond-scale emissive lifetime of the LE emission bands (τ83 K = 298.23 μs and τ298 K = 7.85 μs) indicates the characteristics of phosphorescence, probably originating from the superatom cluster center, while the HE emission arising at low temperature also exhibits microsecond lifetime (τ83 K = 20.17 μs), which tentatively originates from CLCT (cluster to ligand charge transition) modified by the interactions between the metal core and surface ligand, because the site-specific modification and assembly of superatoms led to the distinct difference of HE emission in NC-2, NC-3 (), and SCAM-4 (b). The methylpyridine of NC-3 results in a redshift of HE bands and different temperature-dependent fluorescent color (orange-to-red from 83 K to 293 K) compared with NC-2. For SCAM-4, the HE emission (centered at 518 nm) component becomes more dominated at low temperature (lower than 263 K), while the LE band grows weaker with decreasing temperature and disappears at 83 K, which may be ascribed to the electronic interaction between superatom clusters with the rigid and conjugated π-systems of the linkers. As a result, thermochromism ranging more widely from green to red of SCAM-4 was observed. These findings imply the feasibility of facile modulation of the luminescent properties of the superatomic clusters and cluster-based assembled materials through the appropriate choice of ligand modules or linkers, which may lead to the evolution of novel cluster-based materials with unique properties and functions.

cln_elements.content: (a) Computed optical absorption spectrum of the cluster NC-2 (black) compared to the experimental data (blue). Gray bars show the individual transitions (delta-function-like peaks showing the relative oscillator strengths) (Table S1). The continuous computational spectrum is sums of Gaussian smoothed individual transitions (width of 15 nm). The intensity of the computational spectrum is scaled so that the dominant peaks are approximately of similar intensity. (b) HOMO of NC-2 with its S-symmetric wave function localized at the Ag6 octahedron (isosurface cutoff of 0.04 au) (left), and schematic diagram of s-orbital is shown for illustrative purposes (right). (c) LUMO to LUMO+2 of NC-2 with their P-symmetric wave function localized overall the Ag14 unit (isosurface cutoff of 0.04 au) (left), and schematic diagram of p-orbital is shown for illustrative purposes (right). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

metadata.title:
Atomically
Precise Site-Specific Tailoring and Directional
Assembly of Superatomic Silver Nanoclusters
